ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Union Ice Standard is second to none. Our water filtration and purification systems exceed all national and international standards delivering to you the highest quality ice product available. 

On March 1, 2007 Arctic Glacier Inc. had acquired the assets and operations of The Union Ice Company.

Arctic Glacier Income Fund, through its wholly-owned operating company, Arctic Glacier Inc., is a leading producer, marketer and distributor of high-quality packaged ice to consumers in Canada and the United States, primarily under the brand name of Arctic Glacier; Premium Ice. Arctic Glacier operates 39 production plants and 48 distribution facilities across Canada and the northeastern, central and western United States servicing more than 75,000 retail accounts. Arctic Glacier also licenses its trade names and proprietary technology to independently owned companies in Canada and the United States under franchise and license agreements.

The Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc.'s safety and environmental policies are administered by the Senior Plant Manager with the assistance of the Chief Engineer, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program. 

Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. is a non-responding facility.  The facility's Emergency Coordinators (Chief Engineer, Regional Manager, and/or Senior Plant Manager) have discussed an emergency response plan with the City of Vernon Fire Department (Incident Commander). Administrative Measures:  The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:

- IIAR Bulletin 107, Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie ins 
- IIAR Bulletin 109, Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System
- IIAR Bulletin 110, Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems
- IIAR, A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System

The Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, CalOSHA PSM Program, and EPA RMP Program.  It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility also utilizes fixed ammonia leak detectors to alert personnel of a possible ammonia leak, to call the fire department when the concentration has reached 25 ppm, and to shut down the system at 10,000 ppm.  Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from over-pressurization.

The ammonia leaving the Evaporative Condensers is high pressure liquid which gravity flows into the High Pressure Receiver via the Thermosyphon Receiver in order to repeat the refrigeration cycle.

All process equipment and piping are designed according to ASME standards.   All ASME vessels and compressors are equipped with pressure relief valves which are set to actuate at 250 psig except for the pressure relief valves on the oil pots, oil separator on the compressors, and Evaporative Condensers which actuate at 300 psig.  All relief valves except for the relief valve on the evaporative condensers are tied to a common header that vent to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

- save lives;
- minimize and avoid injuries;
- protect the environment; and
- minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  

Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the supervisor.  The supervisor then notifies the Regional Manager/Senior Plant Manager/Chief Engineer/designee who will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. facility is located at 2970 East 50th Street in Vernon, California, which is located approximately 3.6 miles east of Interstate 110, 3.2 miles west of Interstate 710, and 2 miles south of Interstate 5. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban.  The facility was constructed and began operations in 2006.  

The primary business of Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc. is to produce and distribute ice.  In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 30,850 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the production and distribution of ice.  Typical operating conditions range from 10 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 180 psig on the high side.  Similar to a household refrigerator, there are no expected leaks or releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system at Arctic Glacier Vernon, Inc., which is a closed-loop system.
